summary: human metapneumovirus (hMPV) causes acute respiratory tract infections (ARTIs) in infants and children. hMPV nucleocapsid protein is the most important viral agent responsible for ARIs in children. human metapneumovirus (hMPV) is a recently identified human respiratory pathogen. the viral genome, clinical manifestations, and epidemiology associated with hMPV are similar to those of human respiratory syncytial virus (hRSV) since its initial identification, hMPV infections have been reported worldwide. in the Netherlands, virtually all children have been exposed to hMPV by the age of five. hMPV N protein shares 42-44% homology of amino acid sequence with hRSV. hRSV N protein used as a reference to evaluate the seroprevalence of hMPV infection in china. the purity of both recombinant N proteins was greater than 90%. the purified proteins were confirmed by Western blot analysis using mouse anti-6His tag monoclonal antibody as the primary antibody.
